Questions.Question: Which of the following can be used to find hosts on LAN?
Questions.Explanation: An ARP scan involves iterating over every IP address on a LAN using the ARP protocol to force a reply from any systems.

Answers.Text: Port scanning
ARP scan
Ping sweep
All of the options.

Questions.Question: Using UDP to port scan is easier than using TCP.
Questions.Explanation: TCP is easier to use when port scanning as if a service is available it will always reply with a SYN/ACK packet. UDP port scanning can often be more difficult as services may require a specific input.

Questions.Question: UDP port scanning can rely on using SYN/ACK packets if no response is received.
Questions.Explanation: As UDP port scanning is performed on UDP ports, the TCP protocol cannot be used when UDP port scanning fails.

Questions.Question: T0 is the fastest speed option for port scanning on Nmap.
Questions.Explanation: T0 is the slowest speed option on Nmap. The fastest port scanning option is T5.

Questions.Question: Python and C++ are both more vulnerable to buffer overflows than C.
Questions.Explanation: As C and C++ are both programming languages that give developers flexibility on how memory is managed, it is easier for memory to be mismanaged, opening up the potential for a buffer overflow attack. Languages such as Java and Python are more restrictive, making buffer overflows a lot more rare.

Questions.Question: A vulnerability scanner is a tool designed to detect zero-day vulnerabilities.
Questions.Explanation: Vulnerability scanners cannot be designed to detect zero-day vulnerabilities as they are typically vulnerabilities that are unknown to defenders, with no existing patches to resolve them.

Questions.Question: Which of the following is not a valid payload an attacker can use to remotely execute code?
Questions.Explanation: All of the above options are valid payloads that can be used to remotely execute code.

Answers.Text: Opening a GUI on the victim's end to remotely control it.
Utilising a shell to send commands through.
Creating a backdoor user account to be used by the attacker.
None of the options.

Questions.Question: Network monitoring can detect which of the following:
Questions.Explanation: While network monitoring can detect abnormal patterns, it cannot definitively detect all attacks or always determine whether a user is accessing a network with malicious intent.

Answers.Text: Whether a user is accessing the network with malicious intent.
All of the ways the network is vulnerable to attacks.
Irregular patterns, such as abnormally long connections.

Questions.Question: RCE involves exploiting a service to let attackers:
Questions.Explanation: RCE (Remote code execution) is a type of cyberattack involving an attacker exploiting a service to execute their own code.

Answers.Text: Remotely execute code through a vulnerability.
Rapidly execute code to overload it.
Trigger multiple crashes rapidly to overload it.
Remotely crash a service through a vulnerability.

Questions.Question: It is recommended to assign simple and non-random sequences of numbers as document identifiers as it makes accessing and manipulating resources easier.
Questions.Explanation: Attackers can more easily exploit vulnerabilities to access resources when the identifiers for those resources are easy to determine.

Questions.Question: Which of the following are characteristics of a SQL injection?
Questions.Explanation: SQL injections can be used to access otherwise hidden information, but they can be prevented with proper input sanitisation, among other techniques. They can also affect any database that uses SQL, so they are not limited to only outdated databases.

Answers.Text: Can be used to access information that is otherwise not accessible.
Can only be prevented with input sanitisation.
Is a technique that can only affect outdated databases.
Can be used to access information, that is otherwise not accessible, and can only be prevented with input sanitisation.

Questions.Question: Entering a password as "password' OR '1' = '1' will always grant an attacker access to any account, assuming the entered username is correct.
Questions.Explanation: The attempted SQL injection will fail if a database has proper input sanitisation or has other authentication systems in place.

Questions.Question: A reflected XSS attack is best described as:
Questions.Explanation: A reflected attack is an attack in which a link contains the attack being reflected onto visitors. Visitors can click this link to make the server to reflect the attack onto them.

Answers.Text: An attack where content saved on a page is reflected onto visitors of the website.
An attack where the attacker is able to view a visitor's activity by reflecting their data to the attacker.
An attack where a link contains the attack to be reflected onto visitors.
An attack where a link automatically downloads data onto a visitor's device.

Questions.Question: Which of the following are security options on WIFI:
Questions.Explanation: WIFI networks can be configured to either have no security at all or to have one of several different authentication methods. Some of these methods include using an access list, enterprise authentication or PSK (Pre-shared key).

Answers.Text: No security at all.
Using an access list, based off provided MAC addresses.
Using enterprise authentication.
All of the options.

Questions.Question: What are some characteristics of an open WIFI network?
Questions.Explanation: Open WIFI networks are networks that do not have a password, with traffic also not being encrypted by default. These are more susceptible to packet sniffing due to this lack of encryption.

Answers.Text: The traffic within the network is automatically encrypted.
Is a WIFI network with no password.
Is immune to packet sniffing from attackers.
The network has no password and has automatically encrypted traffic.

Questions.Question: WEP is a newer protocol used for PSK. It is more secure against cyberattacks than WPA.
Questions.Explanation: WEP is an older protocol used for PSK authentication, that is no longer used as it is insecure and susceptible to attacks.

Questions.Question: Which of the following is not a type of penetration testing?
Questions.Explanation: Grey-box testing and white-box testing are both valid types of penetration testing. Variable-knowledge testing is not a real type of testing.

Answers.Text: Grey-box testing
Variable-knowledge testing
White-box testing
Grey-box testing and white-box testing.

Questions.Question: Attackers using social engineering always aim to appear helpful to manipulate victims easier.
Questions.Explanation: Attackers may also play on a victim's fear, among other emotions, to manipulate them.

Questions.Question: Vishing is the act of using emails to get victims to perform actions for an attacker.
Questions.Explanation: Vishing involves using voice messages to manipulate a victim. Typically phone calls are used to achieve this.

Questions.Question: If a user's password manager is compromised their passwords are still fully protected.
Questions.Explanation: A user's passwords can be exposed if their password manager is compromised, despite this, password managers are still a far safer alternative to using the same password everywhere.

Questions.Question: Password-less systems are systems without any form of authentication at all.
Questions.Explanation: Password-less systems often include other forms of authentication, such as biometric authentication.

Questions.Question: Multi-factor authentication allows for users to:
Questions.Explanation: Multi-factor authentication is used to enforce security by making users use multiple authentication methods to verify themselves.

Answers.Text: Access a system without using a password.
Use multiple authentication methods to verify users.
Increase the speed in which authentication takes.
All of the options.

Questions.Question: DAC is used to ensure that users do not have to multi-factor authenticate.
Questions.Explanation: DAC (Discretionary access control) is applied to decide whether a user should need multi-factor authentication. Multi-factor authentication is often needed when a new login location appears, when a significant action is being performed or when a new device is used.
